name: Tyrannosaurus rex
overview: Tyrannosaurus rex is a dinosaur currently documented from Late Cretaceous (68â€“66 million years ago) in Western North America. Current interpretation suggests a carnivore feeding profile. It is typically classified as Theropod. Evidence quality for Tyrannosaurus rex is currently limited by specimen completeness and historical naming complexity. Dino-pedia tracks this taxon with conservative wording so future specimen-level studies can be integrated without overwriting uncertain claims.

externalAppearance.skin: Pebbly, non-overlapping scales (1â€“2 mm) similar to bird feet
externalAppearance.lips: Likely had fleshy lips covering teeth when mouth closed
externalAppearance.coloration: Counter-shaded with mottled greens/browns for camouflage
externalAppearance.displayStructures: Keratin-covered eye ridges possibly brightly colored

huntingAndDiet.strategy: Bone-crushing ambush predator using neck torque to disable prey
huntingAndDiet.biteForce: Equivalent to weight of three school buses
huntingAndDiet.cannibalism: Confirmed by tooth marks on T. rex fossils

environment.climate: Warm, humid, ~10â€“15Â°C hotter than modern North America

reproduction.nesting: Shallow mounds using rotting vegetation for heat
reproduction.medullaryBone: Confirms females produced calcium-rich tissue for eggs

biomechanics.pubicBoot: Pelvic bone used as resting kickstand
biomechanics.footStructure: Arctometatarsalian condition for strength and efficiency

pathologies.brainIssues: Possible vascular tumors in older individuals

funFacts: Could swallow bones whole and digest them
Juveniles filled a completely different ecological niche than adults
Had forward-facing eyes for depth perception
Likely relied heavily on smell to locate carcasses

behaviorAndConflict.territoriality: Large individuals may have defended high-resource territories or carcass zones.
behaviorAndConflict.combatEvidence: Healed bite marks and fractures suggest frequent dangerous encounters.
behaviorAndConflict.socialBehavior: Adults were likely mostly solitary outside breeding periods.
behaviorAndConflict.mainRivals: Other large predators and large herbivores capable of defensive injury.

feedingPatterns.killMethod: Used crushing bite and neck-driven pulls to tear flesh and crack bones.
feedingPatterns.dailyIntake: Likely required tens of kilograms of meat per day, with feast-and-famine cycles after major kills.
feedingPatterns.feedingStyle: Combined active predation with opportunistic scavenging, especially when carcasses were available.
feedingPatterns.foodCompetition: Likely competed with other large theropods and scavengers for carcasses.

breedingAndNesting.parentalCare: Parental presence is plausible but direct evidence is limited.
breedingAndNesting.nestingCycle: Seasonal nesting on elevated, well-drained ground to reduce flood risk.
breedingAndNesting.hatchlingSurvival: Young likely faced high predation pressure and rapid growth requirements.
breedingAndNesting.courtship: Probably used visual display, vocalization, and scent cues during mating seasons.

extinctionContext.immediateEffects: Food-web breakdown reduced large prey availability.
extinctionContext.timeline: Disappeared at the Cretaceous-Paleogene boundary about 66 million years ago.
extinctionContext.legacy: Remains a model species for studying end-Cretaceous megafaunal extinction.
extinctionContext.primaryDrivers: Global ecosystem collapse after asteroid impact and climate disruption.

fossilDiscoveryHistory.majorDiscoveries: Specimens such as Sue and Stan transformed understanding of growth and anatomy.
fossilDiscoveryHistory.museumImpact: T. rex became a centerpiece taxon for public paleontology worldwide.
fossilDiscoveryHistory.researchMilestones: Modern CT scanning and biomechanics studies refined feeding and sensory models.
fossilDiscoveryHistory.firstFinds: Early material was collected in the western United States in the early 1900s.

locomotionAndAthletics.gait: Powerful hindlimb-driven bipedal gait with balanced trunk posture.
locomotionAndAthletics.endurance: Body mass favored efficient movement over sustained high speed.
locomotionAndAthletics.maneuverability: Strong tail and neck coordination supported turning and strike control.
locomotionAndAthletics.acceleration: Likely capable of short-burst acceleration rather than long sprints.

paleoecology.ecosystemRole: Apex predator and top scavenger in terminal Cretaceous ecosystems.
paleoecology.coexistingFauna: Shared habitat with hadrosaurs, ceratopsians, crocodilians, and small theropods.
paleoecology.nicheShifts: Juveniles and adults occupied different ecological roles through growth.
paleoecology.resourceDynamics: Floodplain cycles likely controlled carcass availability and prey movement.

sensoryAndIntelligence.cognition: Behavior likely included flexible feeding decisions and risk assessment.
sensoryAndIntelligence.smell: Large olfactory bulbs suggest excellent scent detection over long distances.
sensoryAndIntelligence.hearing: Inner-ear evidence indicates sensitivity to low-frequency sounds.
sensoryAndIntelligence.vision: Forward-facing eyes provided strong depth perception for target tracking.

researchContext.evidenceBase: Tyrannosaurus rex is represented by published fossil material, but completeness and diagnostic overlap can limit high-confidence biological reconstruction.
researchContext.currentLimits: Several ecological and life-history traits remain inferential rather than directly measured for this taxon.
researchContext.nextDataNeeded: Priority evidence includes better-preserved cranial/postcranial overlap, robust stratigraphic control, and specimen-linked morphometrics.
researchContext.revisionOutlook: Interpretation is expected to improve as new finds and reanalyses clarify taxonomy and anatomy.
